text: so this project is about developing and
trying to test some interventions to
reduce gender bias in STEM fields
particularly and so despite great
progress that we've made over the years
and reducing prejudice against women in
STEM fields we do have a long way to go
so what I'm going to show you are the 10
most recent Nobel laureates and physics
and as you can see they are all of the
same gender
in fact there have only been two women
in the history of the prize in physics
to win this award the first was Marie
Curie in the turn of the century the
more recent one was in 1963 which was
rigged up at Meijer and yeah so this is
one percent of all Nobel laureates and
if we look additionally into existing US
gender disparities among science and
engineering faculty on the x axis are
the carnegie indications of the
different types of institutions and I'll
just be showing you the proportion of
men versus women faculty in each of
these groups and so here you see for the
men across all institutions and here for
the women and so it seems that there
might still be an existing problem and
there's also a lot of empirical work
showing that these disparities still
persist and have a lot of implications
so a study out of MIT has demonstrated
that women faculty tend to have access
to less lab space their lab spaces poor
they're assigned to more committee work
and another a lot of other additional
obligations that reduces their
opportunity for scholarship and female
women's stem students also experience a
report experiencing bias when they're in
graduate school and women are just
generally penalized across a lot of
areas so they're evaluated more poorly
they're less likely to be hired in the
first place they receive less critical
mentoring of their work and they're paid
less and we see this across a lot of
different domains so amongst psychology
job candidates
mathmatics candidates abstracts
acceptance of abstracts amongst and the
field of communications prospective
doctoral student mentoring and even in
science lab manager applicants and so
for this last one what Curran and her
colleagues did was send out applications
identical applications to our one
faculty and I believe biology chemistry
and physics for lab manager applicants
and they saw that when these
applications were labeled as being from
a woman the student was report was
evaluated to be less competent less
hireable and less likely to receive
mentoring and importantly and we'll see
this across the current studies we
really see no effects of any demographic
measures that we've used so regardless
of the faculty participants gender their
age their race or anything else we had
to use these these effects persist so we
see gender bias even amongst women
faculty members and moreover we even see
pretty significant salary disparities so
amongst these students there was a four
thousand a year difference and we know
that because base salaries then are the
basis for promotion these disparities
can get even larger over time and so
currently after doing this work with her
team said how can we actually try to
address this and so the goal is to raise
awareness that bias exists and stem and
to try to reduce it and so I'll show you
some examples of the the intervention
that she used but or we've all used but
there were two points that we really
wanted to emphasize in these
interventions so one was to expose
participants vividly to counter
stereotypic exemplars which have been
shown to be effective in reducing bias
and non-stem related prejudice
situations and then also to to engage
individuals with engrossing media so
betsy levy has done this really
successful in rwanda
in her case with soap operas radio soap
operas and reducing intergroup bias and
conflict and so we wanted to see can we
use such engrossing media ourselves to
reduce bias and and so what Karina and
her team has done is developed 12 high
quality videos and they partnered with
professional playwrights and hired
actors and directors and they wanted to
communicate the results of actual
published bias and research so probably
some of the research that you in this
room have conducted yourself and there
are two primary conditions that we
focused on so one was the narrative
condition and then these six films
participants were shown videos of
entertaining stories with compelling
storylines and consistent characters
throughout the films that were set in a
science department and in the
intellectual condition it was kind of a
Diane Sawyer type interview situation in
which professors who were also actors
which was present the results of the
research to an interviewer in a pretty
straightforward fashion and so
importantly the underlying research that
was presented in these two different
conditions was always the same it was
either presented as an entertaining
storyline or as an interview and so let
me just give you a couple of examples
start there we go
okay a couple of examples of the
Articles that were used so for example
one particular article presented a
finding that these gender stereotypes
can shape the letters of recommendation
in ways that undermine women right that
they write about women in ways that that
hurt their chances of being hired and so
in the intellectual condition this was
just reported by this fake professor in
the narrative condition in a hiring
decision case faculty we're talking over
letters of recommendation from people
who had applied for the position and
then there was also a control
addition in which participants watch
interesting science documentaries which
had equivalent number of men and women
scientists and those had been judged to
be as entertaining as the narrative
condition and as informative as the
intellectual condition but it didn't
include any bias in related information
and so in the first study we recruited
participants from the general population
from MTurk and in this study we had two
time points so first we had participants
respond to our dependent measures
immediately post intervention after
they'd watched the videos and then again
a full six months later and so the DVS
that I'd like to focus on today is the
awareness of bias scale which is a
validated published scale assessing
awareness of bias against women includes
items that now I don't have my notes
that's basically along the lines of
women being evaluated more poorly than
men for the same work and these kind of
things on five-point scales and then to
measure bias directly we use the modern
sexism scale which is frequently used to
assess modern modern ways that sexism
occurs against women and so our
hypothesis was of course that the both
awareness of bias and sexism would be
affected by these intervention movies
versus the control but we don't have a
priori hypotheses about how the
intellectual versus the narrative was
how effective they would be related to
each other
and so first these are the post
intervention results and as you can see
both the narrative and the intellectual
condition did significantly better than
the control condition in raising
awareness of bias immediately after
participants watch the video and so
these were both kind of significant in
this case narrative and the intellectual
did not differ significantly from each
other we did see a small amount of decay
six months later but you can still see a
trend in which the intellectual
condition is doing better and those
those decays are not significant
and then for modern sexism we see a
similar pattern in which in this case
specifically the intellectual condition
reduce bias immediately following
watching the videos relative to the
control identify from there they've been
there they've done different control and
we again see some evidence of
persistence of the effect six months
later so in this first study we showed
especially immediately post intervention
that these intervention movies were
successful in increasing awareness of
bias and reducing modern sexism but we
wanted to know do these findings
generalize so of course if were
interested in bias against women in STEM
fields we'd be interested in knowing how
individuals in STEM fields react to
these videos it might be that many
people in stem are already aware that
these biases exist so they might not
even be effective in this population and
so in the second study we basically
conducted the same study again we
recruited a faculty from across the
United States who had been registered
for the National Academies summer
Institute's on undergraduate education
and in this case we measured
participants at three time points so
first we got baseline measures then one
week later they were exposed to one of
these interventions and we got post
intervention reports and then we also
measured them again one week later and
so with this design we can both look at
change from baseline per intervention so
did a particular movie improve awareness
of bias relative to baseline as well as
the relative change across conditions
and so first you can see that both the
narrative and the intellectual condition
significantly improved awareness of bias
immediately post intervention and each
of these conditions were significantly
different from each other as well and
here with a shorter time span we we see
very strong persistence of these effects
one week later
and then for modern sexism we see a very
similar pattern where again the within
subject change is significant for both
videos and the conditions are
significant from each other
and these these effects persist over
time and so just to summarize we see
some evidence that these videos do
increase awareness of bias against women
in stem and can reduce modern sexism and
so where we'd like to go is first to
assess if we can can actually move
around implicit or automatic biases and
then in addition our team would really
like to be able to disseminate these
videos to training diversity training
groups with appropriate instructions to
actually try to improve this in the real
world and so this leads us to ask okay
well what videos should we use we see
some evidence of both of them being
effective it seemed like the
intellectual was doing better especially
for the scientific community but with
some mediators that I don't have a
chance to discuss today we do see that
that these two types of videos are very
different so the narrative videos were
found to be more engaging people felt
more transported when they watch the
videos where as the intellectual ones
people felt like the information was
presented in a more clear and logical
manner so it might be that you have a
training session where people are
getting a little bit bored it might not
hurt to add some of these narrative
videos and they might also be more
likely to be disseminated informally but
maybe you already have engaging
activities but just not a lot of facts
and so the intellectual videos are a
really great way to share our scientific
findings about gender to a broader
community and so I think in closing we
recognize that that these biases are are
keeping certain members of our community
from from really contributing to science
at their full capacity that hurts
everyone and so hopefully these
interventions are one step to try to
reduce this and really help our
scientific community
we're get its full capacity and so with
that I'd like to of course thank Corinne
from involving me in this awesome
project as well as our other
collaborators Eva Jack Tory and Joe our
funding sources and the great team of
Ras at Skidmore that have been helping
us with us as well thank you very much
